Literature Review: Partialing, a statistical approach used to remove extraneous variance from a variable, has been widely employed in clinical research to control for confounds and make inferences about the nature and effects of variables. However, despite its intuitive appeal, partialing is fraught with undesirable consequences when predictors are correlated. This literature review aims to examine the effects of partialing on variables, review analytic approaches commonly used in clinical research, and discuss the limitations and potential consequences of partialing. We will also explore alternative approaches to partialing and provide recommendations for reducing or eliminating problematic uses of partialing.

References.title: The Problem with Partialing
References.authors: Kenny, D. A., & Bollen, K. A.
